reviews.text:
This park is absolutely theft of money. The entry price is 2200 yen so we logically thought that it covers every attraction inside. Practically besides the short shows of ninjas and little buildings that represent the antique way of japan’s Life style the rest cost money! There is huge amount of attractions inside and all of them costs between 500 -2000 ten each .
The shows are only in Japanese( except one in English ) so if you are tourists please save your precious time and do not go there. We were there for about 2 hours basically doing nothing and tried to understand what for they took from us such big amount of money .
 This park suits only Japanese people or people that has no problem of waisting a lot of money.

Samurai sword fighting and ninja shows! Unfortunately the dialogue is in Japanese. The attractions were great - we did the haunted house, ninja mystery house, and trick art museum. The ninja mystery house is kind of an escape room experience. Great food options on-site.

If you speak Japanese maybe you can have a nice visit... EVERYTHING is in Japanese- almost NO ENGLISH !!! 
You pay 2200 yen for entrance and it's doesn't cover the attractions inside - you need to pay another 500 yen for each if them extra.. 
Buildings and film area are nice but not worth to pay so much. 
Also I got the feeling stuff really didn't care about foreign tourist there...again no english and no help at all. 
This is not Disneyland - don't go here!!

This would be a great family outing or a place for anyone interested in film history or samurai culture. The tour was interesting and the film museum was surprisingly good. I especially enjoyed the samurai sword practice. Other activities were an extra charge and the food was a bit limited.

Don't go in the low season, they charge you full price but don't tell you 75% of the shops and attractions are closed (you also have to pay for the attractions separately once inside). The small shows they did put on were enjoyable

A pleasant pedestrian walkway that has a lot of history but not a lot of "there" there. I think it might seem underwhelming given the extent to which people talk about it because it pretty much looks like any other bridge. It pays to keep in mind that the historical value of a place is often why it receives a lot of recognition. The role this bridge played in connecting this area can't be overstated so keep that in mind when you see it.

Well since it was just before the Sakura flowers bloomed, it wasn't as beautiful as it would have been. But still and enjoyable sight.
The boat rides available there are great. Would recommend anyone to take a house boat ride or if you can row rent a boat there. It's a wonderful experience.
One surprise was the boats that sell cooked  food and fresh fruits come right up to the boats and while you are on the boat you can buy from them. Didn't expect that in Japan.

So much to see and so much to zen energy to embrace. The view from this bridge offers not only the relaxing and beautiful view, but also the opportunity to access different shrines and shoppes near by. A great experience to have when in Japan and FREE.

1. No idea what the fuss about this bridge was
2. Call me shallow
3. I rmb i had a friend who identified herself as a "bridge enthusiast"
4. You might give 5 stars if you are her

Nice enough bridge - lots to do on either side. Looks to be undergoing construction as of this time (Feb 2019). 

You will walk across this bridge when going towards the Monkey Park. 

Picturesque views especially on the mountain side. 

At the end of the day though, it's just a bridge so I wouldn't target this for a day trip or anything.

Great Hike, Fresh Air, Highly Recommended!
The goal I recommend in reaching this destination is to explore anything and anywhere that capture your interest, that's what make the experience even more worth it. The Garden can be misleading and hidden make sure after your tea ceremony you find the garden. It's worth exploring and enjoying. THE VIEW is mindblowing and you can even enter a Japanese style home: just make sure you remove your shoes.

We walked through this garden as the bamboo forest was disappointing and we loved it. Would make the trip just for this garden and beautiful Japanese architecture. We were lucky as there were only a few other here which probably added to its charm.

Peaceful and gorgeous garden whose price tag (1000 yen) keeps away the hords of tourists. There is a "hidden" house when you start going down where you can just sit on a Tatami, write a few words at some tables and watch the garden. Very relaxing after the frustrating grove.
A short hike to a lovely garden with a view. You do have to pay an entrance fee but it's worth it. It includes tea and a treat.
Probably the best garden in Arashiyama. Definitely worth the entry price.

I loved this place! Such a nice change of pace to the temples and shrines. Great to stretch the legs and get the heart rate up. The hill is tame with rest spots to catch your breath if you need but really only takes 20 minutes. Feeding the monkeys was a real joy and the view of Kyoto from the top is fantastic. It all seems to be really well managed.

I loved this. This was a bit of a hike to get to the top, about 20 minutes but so worth it. The monkeys are everywhere! Plus there is a great view from the top! I highly recommend spending the 100 yen to feed them. One of my favorite things we did in Kyoto!

Oh my Goodness loads of fun and romantic. I felt safe and it felt like a controlled environment. Everything was beautiful and the monkeys are cute and photogenic. The souvenirs were a good price and feeding the monkeys was the best. Definitely go! Its a bit of a hike so little ones might have a hard time but there are plenty of rest stops on the way up. Please keep in mind it is a hike up a mountain. Well worth it tho!

Be warned, the hike is steep!!! I recommend taking it easy. My favorite part was feeding the monkeys in the rest area. Its nice to see the monkeys have this kind of freedom. The staff there is friendly. The area is not shaded well so the sun does burn a bit. Once you complete the hike, there is a nice view of Kyoto. You can see Kyoto Tower with the naked eye. Although I did not enjoy the exercise part, the monkeys were cute and definitely worth it.

The trek up is a good workout but well worth the trip. The views are stunning and especially in the spring months. Again not much information about the park and the work that is being done with the monkeys is available. 

We did the trek with 2 kids (6 & 8) in the afternoon. Monkeys at the end were a motivating factor to climb. They were fine and found it easy to do.
Really cool temple to check out. All the stone carved faces are fun to see as well

This temple was an absolute hidden gem.  Arashiyama on the weekend was extremely packed, suffocatingly so.  I rented a bike from the local shop and took a ride, with the goals of finding a good view of the city and escaping the crowds. This led me up the mountain to the northwest of Arashiyama.  Nestled in a ravine, you'll find this shrine.  Came around 1 pm and there weren't many tourists there at all.

A lot of interesting carvings, with different sorts of moss growing everywhere. Reminded me of shadow of the colossus.
Amazing temple, 300 yen if I remember well. Look like nothing you've seen before and the way to come here is so beautiful, like traditional houses.
After visiting bamboo forest, check this out..buy a full day trip ticket for the bus. It is a nice place to visit.

What a beautifull and happy temple. The true meaning of zen.
300yen per person, you get a panflet with the history of the temple.

The temple itself is quite peaceful, it has a nice story, and, most importantly, there are almost no people there at all. It is a bit further away from the "mainstream" temples, so maybe that's why. I'm giving it 4 stars because the bamboo path is currently closed for renovation, yet it didn't affect the price (Y500).

I suggest this place for those highly interested in Buddhism and history. It is a small park inside but very peaceful. Located inside is also a graveyard with headstones. You can see locals coming to pay respect. The stone statues inside each represents a soul without kin to see them off to afterlife. 
There’s an entrance fee 500yen.
It was beautiful. But part of it was closed, so couldn't see all of it. Compared to the other shrines in the area it isn't worth the ¥500 entrance fee.
I went here in autumn and it was beautiful. Very quiet and serene. Go early to get the entire place to yourself.

Lovely grave stones.
Bamboo grove was under construction and not accessible.
I think it must be great if I could enter the bamboo grove as well as its photo is very nice.

This is the type of place you would want to include in a Journey, but not make it the key part of it. If you are walking around in Arashiyama, it's worth coming here. There is this temple and another right next door. The other one is famous because of the moss garden, but it's also full of people. This one doesn't have anything fancy, but not too many people come here. It's an ideal resting place, it's quite and cool. Come here to take a break, sit and enjoy the surrounding vegetation. When we were there it was only us, we had the whole place to ourselves literally.

It doesn’t worth paying entrance fee.
The place is ruined and not taken care of.

This temple is not worth the journey for itself, it is minimal and a bit run down, but still quite beautiful. If you are going to Gio-ji it is an easy addition. It is very much an "explore as you feel" temple

The moss gardens here are beautiful!
Quiet, peaceful location.  Away from central Arashiyama.  A bit of a hike/walk to get to, but worth the side trip.
Beautiful mossy grounds, very peaceful and great bamboo groves
Great staff and beautiful gardens and temple shrines. A great way to get away from the crowds at the nearby bamboo grove.
Worth the hike up the steps thru an expansive cemetery to see a great view of the city
Walk up some stairs, it’s calm and quite at the higher ground of the temple. The sound of birds and bell (when someone gongs the bell near by) is very soothing.

Went to the bamboo forest which was pretty disappointing but walked up the hill to this. Continue up the big staircase at the back to find amazing views out over the city. Very peaceful and interesting place. No one around when we visited which made it even better.
Quiet but not that interesting
Giant Buddha! Likely to be busy but definitely worth a visit. There's also a museum you can get access to (optional).

Far from the crowds. You may be alone here!
That is reason enough to visit. It's beautiful. Nice garden. Great wooden walkway. An a unique gallery of artifacts. Been to over 30 kyoto temples, that gallery was a first.

Seiryō-ji, a Buddhist temple, in Arashiyama section of Kyoto, retains Japanese Buddhism culture and tradition. The temple seems to have long history with Chinese Buddhism by going back to Chinese Tang Dynasty of the 7th century, and its Buddhist aetiface collection in the main hall seems to document its close tie with Chinese and Indian Buddhism.

Because it is NOT located at Arashiyama train station, bridge, or bamboo glove areas, which are more popular and known for the tourists, its about 10-minute walking distance from Arashiyama train station actually offers it an unique Buddhist serenity and quietness without much noise or loud talking of the tourists. 

The rear area of the temple, which requires moderate admission fee to enter, exhibits Buddhist practice- including sitting, writing- building design and architect, and chatting and learning with and from Buddhist Masters who are friendly and patient. The rear section of the temple has an unique traditional wooden walkway to connect the front main hall. The rear section of the temple also has unique but tranquil garden of flower trees and moss on the garden floor.

The rear-garden Zen or sitting worship room offers worshipers for writing Buddhism pray or so called NO-evil behaviors pledges, and worshipers are allowed to leave their writing in the front of the worship room, with or without donations, and monks will pray for the believers, 

During Chinese Cultural Revolution, many Japanese universities, including Kyoto University, had wide-spread student unrest on campus which caused campus lock-up. Because of his academic relations with various religious and history scholars of Kyoto University, Master Monk of Seiryo-ji Temple, who was a famous history scholar, offered help to foreign visiting scholars to Kyoto University for temporary residence in the temple.    

In April, Seiryo-ji Temple will have its annual tradition for traditional drama show to represent the kick off of traditional Japanese drama season.

The Temple also holds two times per year for its collection of  Buddhist art, mainly 10th century statutes,  and generally it is held and open for the  visitors in April and Oct-Nov. The admission is 300 yen in 2018.

Staff at the front reception or admission office do know some foreign language, including English, and they are willing to help visitors by hand signs or other measures.  Some of the staffs are volunteers, including cleaning workers.

While temple is serene and peaceful overall,  visitors can feel that strong sense of humanity and classic wooden building walkway in the rear garden of the temple. In rear garden, visitors can also write visiting impression and reflection on the visitors books.  Visitors can also write their "Promise for Doing Goodness" and make special prayer or wish on the Japanese tatami Zen practice or sitting worship room which has Buddha image in the front center.  The Zen practice room provides a rare seclusion for relaxation and reflection with quietness, when Arashiyama is becoming more and more crowded with noise.

The temple's simple but beautiful garden has cherry blossom trees and other flower trees in Spring and In Autumn.

Visitors coming out the temple's main gate may want to turn left and stop by at the Japanese bean curd store which is one of the Kyoto's oldest bean curd makers and which always has numerous home town buyers from Kyoto for its daily fresh-make bean curds. Tourists can also buy and try the just-make bean curd at the store. 

Walking to Seiryo-ji Temple is about 6 to 8 minutes of walking distance from JR Arishiyama train station or Keifuku [Randen] Line Arashiyama train station.

My favourite temple that I visited on this trip. After walking around the temple grounds, have a seat on the tatami mats in the main hall and gaze at the historical Shakyamuni statue. If it was not modified when the historical replica was made in China centuries ago, could just well be looking at the historical Buddha’s likeness when he was 37 years old. Gave me the feels.... very polite and smiling staff here. Just 400 Yen per adult entry fees, I don’t mind, it helps to maintain the place.
Pretty big temple. Nothing special but good walk for a free entrance

I love walking along the river to temple. Nothing much in temple, but staffs are very kind and friendly; trying to explain everything even I don’t know Japanese , I was able to understand. It was a rainy day so I didn’t see much of the view. I think it would be worth for visit on sunny day.
Serene and meditative...best stop in Arashiyama. Easy hike up stairs with resting points if needed.
You can expect some breathtaking views and a friendly conversation in the guest sitting room. Highly recommended place off the beaten path.

While temple's worship hall is old and shabby, its Buddhist sitting hall or Zen Practice Hall is super with extraordinary natural view and breezing wind.   Visitors have to climb upward steps from river bank or riverbank road to the temple, and it may take a few minutes for step climbing to reach the temple. The slate steps are old and sometimes broken, and visitors should take time for climbing.

Staffs, including Master Monk, are very friendly, while Master Monk can command English without difficulty, although he is not always staying at the temple.  It seems that master monk is trying hard in the last few years to renovate the temple building structure and improve temple design and decoration.  One of its major funding methods is from its Zen Sitting Course which is offered to Buddhist believers and non-Buddhist believers, including foreigners.  Sometimes, foreign visitors would take boat from Togetsu Kyo Bridge and get off the river bank near the temple area. 

While visitors can take boat near Togetsu Kyo Bridge area, it is worthy while for tourists or visitors to walk across the bridge and walk along the river bank road [which is relatively narrow and is used by one nearby Hotel for the supply delivery] to the temple, because its river scene is extraordinarily beautiful and its river breeze is relatively comfortable. The walk generally takes 15 minutes before a few minutes of climbing. Temple does charge a moderate admission for the entrance, while it offers tea, free of additional charge, to the visitors. Also, visitors are allowed to walk around the Zen Sitting Room and take photos. If master monk is there, visitors may feel free to chat with master monk, who is very friendly and casual, although he is often bare foot in spring and summer time.

Visitors are also allowed to knock the temple bell three times to liberate themselves.

In my October 2018 visit, I found that temple does add a few wood benches along the slate step trail for visitors to take a break while climbing up, about 5 to 8 minutes climb.
Amazing view, but requires a long walk up to the top by some steep stairs. Not advisable for weak people on the hot summer. Fee is ¥400 but visit this only if you like silence.

The Katsura Imperial Villa is a must when visiting Japan. Gardens are completely beautiful, you can have a deep dive in how the emperadors enjoyed nature. The Villa’s architecture is so smart and delicate. The tour takes less than 1 hour and reservation is requiered to visit the Villa.

You need to apply at least 3 weeks in advance to come to this garden but it will be worth it. Definitely the best garden in Japan that I have seen. You will also need to bring your passport to enter. Our guide Miki was fluent in English, very friendly and welcoming, and extremely knowledgeable. Be aware that there may not be taxis available here (ie you may need to walk to the train station).

If you only have the chance to see one garden while you're in Kyoto, I suggest Katsura. A reservation is required, as it is for most of the famous gardens, and the tour moves quickly. If I could, I'd ask them to just let me sit in one place for an hour so that I could pain there, but such is life. If I make it back to Japan, I'll definitely go here gain.

Katsura is a beautiful example ok Japanese garden and traditional, historic Architecture. We went in late November and the leaves were changing color and it was incredibly beautiful. This place only allows you to go on a scheduled tour so check the timing ahead of time. This is good though, because it isn't overrun with people like most other temples in Kyoto. You can great great photos and have a more tranquil experience.

I have refrained from posting my pictures of Katsura Villa, simply because it is that beautiful of a place. I do not want to spoil it. 

The landscape is a series of impeccably planned twists and turns, dips and rises. Walking between the multiple pavilions, every step reveals new scenery. 

To visit, make a reservation on the imperial household agency website. Or walk in to try and get a ticket (there's a limited quota daily). Tickets cost 1000yen.  

English tours are available at certain timeslots. Audio guides in multiple languages are also available, so no worries even if you can only get the Japanese tour. This is important because you can only enter with a tour.
Quiet place to meditate in a beautiful environment. Monks are very friendly here.

this is not the place for foreigner that can't understand japanese language the zen monk will only edify in japan you will waste the time about 30 minute if you can't not understand  
and the admission free is 500 yen

Formaly named a Kegon-ji Temple but commonly known as Suzumushi-dera Temple named after the thousands of bell crickets (suzumushi) that are reared all year round. It costs 500 JPY as admission fee but worth of it. You can enter the Suzumushi room, hear the preach(in Japanese thou) and have some green tea.

Sweet little garden. Don't forget to give your name and city to the Guardian at the entry so he comes to your place with his sandals to grant your wish.
The Buddhist preach is only in Japanese so I didn't visit the temple. Staff is very nice and warned me in perfect English. 300y
An interesting temple with a lively talkative monk. It was really enjoyable.
Very pleasent experience for a themed cafe. Pricey but the experience is worth it(at least for my wife)
Absolute must visit if you're a Rilakumma fan. Lots of merchandise that can only be found here. Prices are reasonable, from cheap souvenir items to quality leather goods.
this place so cozy and the waiters so passion.. i like the taste of their cakes, you can try it when you come to arashiyama bamboo groove 😁
Cute yes...a lot of empty tables when I went upstairs to check at 11.30 and they work very slow and make customers queue and wait for half an hour and wasting time.
Very very cute store 🎁💕

A reservation through their website is necessary to eat there. It will ask for a deposit, the instructions are simple, you will need to confirm the reservation number once you get there. Very close to Arashiyama Bamboo Forest so if you can arrange your schedule ahead, it'd be perfect. A bit pricey but you do pay for the quality. We had the eel with rice and we coud taste the difference. I'd recommend trying at least once.

I am an Unagi fan and I may have tried most of the best Unagi in this planet.

+ Quite good in terms of the price / quality.
+ Great Location and could quite align with part of the tourist plan.
+ Variety choices of food as an Unagi speciality restaurant.
- The dinning pace too fast, like fast food.

Delicately cooked eel with a tad less sauce than other Unagi bowls I've had (outside Japan) but the flavours were just perfect. Texture of the meat  was heavenly. Queue forms even before the restaurant opens and there was only about 8 tables; was there about 30 minutes before opening and had to wait for two complete seatings. The also might seat 1 person to a four person table, so that does increase the wait.

Long wait to get in. Recommend getting there 45-60 minutes before they open to get a seat quickly.

Food was outstanding. Eel was perfect texture and sauce was perfectly sweet/savoury without being overpowering. Eel liver skewer was a really highlight of the meal.

It was on the way to bamboo forest, hard to miss. There was a long line when I was heading to see the bamboos. On my way back the line got so short so we decided to have lunch here. You order as you wait in line. Most people just choose sets rather than just getting the unagi rice. So did we, the appetizers were all made from eel, which was great. The unagi rice is not as saucy as other places allowing you to really focus on the taste of the fish. Once you sit down food comes rather quickly.  It is rather expansive but it’s a great place to try amazing unagi. The pickled/salted vegetable to go with the rice were awful though.

Lucky for us the cherry blossoms were in bloom. This was right by our hotel so was an easy stop for us. Inside of the castle costs more to tour and basically consists of painted murals. These are also reproductions as the originals are in the museum. The interior architecture was impressive and they had a lot of written information regarding the castle and it's inhabitants. I found it informative. The garden is beautiful and a great place to check out cherry blossoms! Overall we were able to do this in about 2 hours, but we totally took our time and read all of the informational signs.

Beautiful castle.  It has moat!!!  Well it's water but still pretty damn cool.  

Expect to spend a lot of time here. It's on the expensive side of 600 Yen. 

This castle is massive!  We tried to blow through it all but we still spent around 2 hours taking pictures.   You can easily spend more. 

You have to be in decent shape to reach all interest points.  The look out deck is on top of very steep stairs so be careful. 

No ramps for wheelchairs but the Japanese are GANGSTER they don't need ramps.  

Fat Americans (like me) beware!  You'll have to walk a ton here.

This was a really nice castle, for $6 I really felt like I got my money's worth.  The grounds are quite big and the main castle itself was wonderful. Although you can't take pictures inside the castle the shoe pile was worthy and the gardens and gates make for some good shots.

It is a good place to take time and go around. The building and little waterway look beautiful. The castle has a little yard inside that is good to sit down and relax. The building itself offers plenty to see. It is not famous compared to other castles like osaka but this place is far more attractive. Go visit this place if you have time.

Beautiful castle and a nice place to walk around and learn about the history of Japan. The gardens are beautiful. There are lockers to put your stuff in and a small cafeteria for snacks if you spend more time here. The Nightingale corridors in the castle were very cool!!

Very convenient location, right in the middle of town with most places of interest within or near walking distance though you might need to take public transportation to places further and the bus stop is in front of the hotel. 
Local foods and fast food restaurants are around too.

Room size is alright for two persons as we're out most of the day but the bathroom/toilet is a bit small and cramped.
We can overlook that as the friendly staff and convenient location makes up for it.

I will definitely go back for my next visit.

Clean and great location. However as a smoker, there's no smoking room nor in the lobby. You've to walk a few minutes outside of the inn as the area is entirely smoke-free. Air-conditioning has no heating or cooling either, just delivery of air.

Nice hotel. Staff are very friendly and it carries any items you may have forgotten. Rooms are a good size and is exactly what you expect from a hotel. Very close to the river where there are many small alleys with shops and restaurants.
Staff very helpful. Comfortable rooms with everything you'd need. If out late no problems leaving keys as open 24-7.
Nice place at a good location
No 御朱印? Well OK then. Pretty disappointing experience, everything interesting under renovation and no seal. Cool but definitely not a good time to go.
Immense. Right in the heart of the city, near the station. Not very busy. Easy to explore at your own pace. Should take off shoes before stepping onto the wooden stairs.

This is one of the biggest temple in Japan, and it is pretty close to Kyoto station. Don't miss the Main Hall, the Daisho-in Hall and the majestic Karamon gate with beautiful carvings. It is a Unesco World Heritage Site, and not to be missed!

It's a lovely place to visit if your out and about In Kyoto, it has beautifully architecture and a lovely land scape they even have English tours available there for tourists and its a really fascinating place I would recommend checking it out.
If you have never been to Japan, you should pay a visit here for a first "buddhist shrine experience". One of the many main center for Buddhism.
Beautiful garden. Well maintained and aesthetically arranged. It is not big, but not crowded. Nice change of pace from crowd and busy area.
Nice little garden. Not expensive. Beautiful during Spring and cherry blossoms

This is a rating for the winter experience: Not worth it. There's a 800 yen fee (I believe, or it was 500?). But every single teahouse inside is closed, a bridge was closed for renovations, and the trees were pretty barren. For the winter season, it's not really worth visiting or looking at. Its definitely okay, just not really worth it.
Not the greatest gardens in Japan. But could be good on a summer's day as you can sit on the grass

Shōsei-en is ea garden that belongs to Higashi-Hongan-ji, the big temple of the True Pure Land School of Buddhism just north of Kyoto station. The garden is said to have belonged to the residence of the son of tennō Saga and was built in the early Heian period. Beautiful and heart warning.

We were lucky enough to get a free entrance pass from the tourist information counter just below the tower, so please check them out for any discount coupons and freebies before going up the tower. The night view on the tower is magnificent, but I'm sure the day view will be as great as the night view too.

The Kyoto tower is impressive in every aspect. The view from it is so beautiful, specially at night when the city is completely illuminated. It has shops inside, where you can buy many different kind of snacks and sweets, it has as well a shop to rent Kimono.
Great place to go if you need ideas on what to do in Kyoto. Admission is a bit pricy, but great for tourists. It has an interactive displayed h can show you the sights at different times of the day.

A rather confusing building, shared between a hotel and various weird shopping malls. The place also smells dreadful. You have to use a combination of stairs and elevators. Once you are up there, the views are great and plenty of free binoculars.. 360 degree views Hard to find your way out again.
We don't see the tower from the top but you can enjoy the view from the below ( station). This building have food court also
They don't speak English. Polite but still rushing you to get moving even though there is no line. Also, it is cash only.
Nice English speaking staff.  Good service. You can buy  stamps.

Did not realize it was a National holiday (vernal equinox). The post office near my hostel closed, and without information on opening hours specified in Google Map, I just tried my luck here :) Staff was efficient and polite to foreigners, and they understood English. One word of caution in posting packages overseas. Just stating "cosmetics" in the description of goods won't do. You need to specify the details, e.g. Face cream x2, Lip balm x3. I was asked to remove sunscreen and hair dye from my package, as they were prohibited items.

I have a credit card shipped here from another city where I lost it, I wasn't able to pick it up here because it wasn't delivered during my stay, but the staff was very diligent each time I went to check.

Great service!
¥70 - for international post card
¥110 - for international envelop

This beautiful place is definitely worth a visit! It is completely free to have a fully guided tour but make sure you either book ahead online or turn up earlier in the day to book on to a tour slot as they are likely to sell out! Do make sure you have a piece of ID as well when you book and when you arrive for your tour.

The tour is conducted only in Japanese but they provide audio guides free of charge to foreigners like me! The audio guides give plenty of information but are on the quiet side!

There are lockers provided free of charge at the entrance where you can leave any rucksacks or shopping, which is a bonus!

The gardens are beautiful! We went in winter but it sounds like there will be something different to see in each season!

Huge, nice, quiet and relaxing place. It's not overcrowded but you need a reservation and a guide to get in. However, the surrounding park is also very large, nice and quiet and you can visit it at any time without need to worry about the entrance.

Probably the best Japanese garden I've seen. There are only FREE, limited guided tours (3 per day, about 35 persons) that you need to book in advance on the internet or next to the entrance during the morning. The tour is in Japanese, but audio guides are offered in several languages for free upon arrival. You must follow the indicated route with the guide, but unlike other Japanese gardens in Kyoto you have plenty of space and time to enjoy the views and take your pictures. The buildings around are not that impressive, but they have some interesting story behind. A totally recommended visit while in Kyoto. Personal tip: Be at the entrance about 11 to get reserve your ticket (bring your passport!), book for the 2 or 3 PM slot and go to the Nijo castle while you wait.
Nice place to stroll and watch Sakura in Spring

I have never left a bad review for any establishment but, I have to give a negative one for this site. Just to let you know that I got an application for a tour to this place, with a lot more slots  a week in advance.  They don’t confirm or at least let you know that application was declined. Called , no one answering. 
After commuting and walking to the site , i showed my screenshot application- no one was there for the tour just my wife and i . Still - that’s a no go. Anyway, just for those applying - i guess call several times if you id not get email.  Entire day a mess- ugh
Booked for a table of 20 for a hen do. The food was amazing!! And the service was great too. Highly recommended. Email contact was prompt to sort details. Thanks
Good food and a great cooking experience as they cook in front of you. Quite exhilarating.
Awesome food, good fun if you have teppanyaki. Great service, reasonably priced too. I'm definitely going back next time I'm in Chester!
Very yummy menu, good quality and not too expensive. Good vibe and attentive waiting staff.
Excellent and authentic food! Nice ambience and good staff. Would highly recommend.
Pretty decent  & tasty meals for $7 a dish. there's English menu..  Lots of international tourist here. friendly l staff.. a bit too salty yakisoba ..
combination of local food & western dishes on the menu, the price are reasonable too.

Fantastic place to eat, food was delicious and the waitress we had was extremely helpful and attentive to our table.

Wide choice of food and menu was readable in English. Smoking and none smoking areas are in the same room, with no barrier between, however we sat in the none smoking area and the air conditioning seemed to take care of the smell of smoke.

Good food and reasonably priced with great staff.
Food here are awesome and half a price from outside!! Come with several choice and the beer are Power Pac, good to try.

Slow service, took ages after table was ready to order before waiting staff attended and even that seemed like a fluke, chicken sticks had cartledge strewn through them. Beef dish was nice but a little salty however.
We've had beautiful meals in fantastic places served by the friendliest staff on our trip to Japan - this place however is NOT one on that list.

Very convenient location, right in the middle of town with most places of interest within or near walking distance though you might need to take public transportation to places further and the bus stop is in front of the hotel. 
Local foods and fast food restaurants are around too.

Room size is alright for two persons as we're out most of the day but the bathroom/toilet is a bit small and cramped.
We can overlook that as the friendly staff and convenient location makes up for it.

I will definitely go back for my next visit.

Clean and great location. However as a smoker, there's no smoking room nor in the lobby. You've to walk a few minutes outside of the inn as the area is entirely smoke-free. Air-conditioning has no heating or cooling either, just delivery of air.

Nice hotel. Staff are very friendly and it carries any items you may have forgotten. Rooms are a good size and is exactly what you expect from a hotel. Very close to the river where there are many small alleys with shops and restaurants.
Staff very helpful. Comfortable rooms with everything you'd need. If out late no problems leaving keys as open 24-7.
Nice place at a good location
Nice staff, good drinks at cheap price and also food is cheap. Quality is ok.
Hard to communicate in English yet there is a machine you can order easily ^^
Good and cheap yakitori with a multi-language touchscreen ordering system.
早朝まで営業してる。 タッチパネルで注文するスタイル。 トイレも広くてきれかった。 トータルしていやすいお店。
鳥貴族はよく行きますが、こちらのお店は分煙されていて嬉しいです。服が臭くならないのでナイスです。

Great food, great service. Fluent English. Closes late, while most of the surrounding places are closed  already or reservation only.... super clean and the way they decorate the dishes is just beautiful.

Options galore--and everything is delicious. They have an English menu and don't be shy about flagging someone down to order. We ordered everything from the tempura brie, sushi bowl, salads and my favorite the sea-bream gills. Great place to duck into and feel like a local-- pub-like atmosphere with top shelf food and late night hours.
Great food and efficient-yet-friendly service at an affordable price.

Enjoyed every menu we ordered - karaagae, yakitori(thigh with green onion), cheese tempura, gyoza, potato salad and so on. I guarantee you’d never be disappointed with any menu in this izakaya. Its service was perfect, was not too loud, not too crowded, and price was reasonable. I and my sister were so satisfied with all aspects and would very love to revisit here if we can ! By that time, hopefully it will not get so famous that we have to wait for like hours lol. 
P.S. Its House White wine is awesome!
Favorite izakaya in Kyoto. Amazing food and sake. Try the sashimi, dumplings, yakatori, whole grilled onion and the cucumbers. So so good!
The view is very nice. Day time or night time. The food price of course is for high class. You can enjoy the surrounding area like malls, river and even the busker will entertain you.
Many restaurant, beautiful view with the cherry blossoms and the river. Go here at the end of your day and have a bit to eat. Most restaurant open st 17:00
Maybe a tourist trap. However, it's one of the best places I've ever been. Truly unique

This is a must place to visit in Kyoto, especially at night. We loved the shops, the narrow alley, and as a bonus we got to see a real Geisha! From Takoyaki to sake bars this area has it all! Be aware of the cover charges for most places. There are some cheap eats and very expensive ones too. Our favorite spot was just off the alley called the Sake Bar.
Nice alley with plenty of eateries of all sorts including steak & wine places and izakaya style great for drinks. Right by the river and many restaurants offer a nice view

Very convenient location, right in the middle of town with most places of interest within or near walking distance though you might need to take public transportation to places further and the bus stop is in front of the hotel. 
Local foods and fast food restaurants are around too.

Room size is alright for two persons as we're out most of the day but the bathroom/toilet is a bit small and cramped.
We can overlook that as the friendly staff and convenient location makes up for it.

I will definitely go back for my next visit.
