Staff very helpful. Comfortable rooms with everything you'd need. If out late no problems leaving keys as open 24-7.
Nice place at a good location

Visited here as part of a walking tour. It was worth the walk uphill. It was stunning with the beautiful dark orange buildings and the surrounding cherry blossom trees. Every angle was picturesque.
A lot of people  come here dressed in Kimonos and full traditional hairstyles with makeup for pictures. 
The reading leading up to it has lots of souvenir shops with lots of interesting  handmade Japanese items.
A must visit  place  if you are in Kyoto.

Must-see if you're in Kyoto! Make sure you have cash with you as there was no ATM within at least 15 min walking distance. Ensure you're comfortable walking as you'll only be able to reach the temple after going up an old street with numerous shops selling sweets, clothes (kimonos), tea, pickled vegetables, etc. People dress up in kimonos which was lovely to see. It gets pretty busy, so be warned if this is not your thing. The temple is stunning, the autumn leaves made everything look serene.

Very beautiful place. Nice contrast with cherry blossom. Unfortunately, main building is under construction. I recommend to go night time. It has nice atmosphere. They do night viewing until 4/7. Must see!!

Absolutely loved this temple. The atmosphere was a little chaotic as there are many tourists, however it's still manageable. You can see Kyoto the more you ascend, and get a great view of the surrounding land. The temples themselves are lovely to look at. The vendors as you make your way to the temple also have a great amount to offer. You have the options of various snacks and souvenirs to purchase on your way up or down.

Beautiful temple, especially during cherry blossom season and at night. Despite going at night, there was still a huge crowd. I have been told the sunset is amazing from up there, but we missed it. You must walk up a steep windy road to get there but the road is filled with shops and food stands, so there is plenty of spots to rest of the. The way up. At one point the road becomes a pedestrian road, so you don't have to worry about cars.

This was a really unique experience. The 1000 statues are incredibly well kept and very beautiful. It was also covered and it happened to be a rainy day so the timing was perfect. I thoroughly enjoyed the descriptions of each statue and what they represented. They have prayer boxes for each, I gave my 5 cents to the thunder god whom is said to control the weather. Once we had left the temple the clouds had cleared up, best nickel I've ever spent. 

I would share some pictures but photography is forbidden inside. So make sure you keep the cameras off.

Amaaaaazing! The garden is great but the most interesting point is the interior. The 500 statues with the huge statue in the middle of these are just incredible. I never seen something like that before. Highly recommended!
Absolutely gorgeous place. Felt very peaceful inside. Will definitely want to visit again.
One of my favorite temples. Not too much crowd, so it felt peaceful walking/sitting around the garden. The statues and the big buddha inside the temple is stunning!

Probably the most educational temple visit ever. There are detailed signs explaining the faces and significance of all the statues, of which there are many to begin with.

A friendly stranger even reminded me that I shouldn't be praying here like it was a shrine. Woops, lol.

This temple is very long and every inch of that space is put to use.
Seeing the blood on the ceiling was one the historical highlights of my entire trip. It’s very morbid, but right up my alley.
This is another beautiful buddhist temple in Kyoto. There is no admission fee to walk around the grounds but I don't believe you can actually enter the temple itself.

Small temple with hundreds years old bloody footprints and stains on the ceiling! (It was once the floor in another residence) It is all Japanese, but there was a nice guy explaining it in broken English. Highly recommended.
Don't pay to enter the two room tour, it's not in English. But the ceiling is made out of the floor where samurai's bleed to death at Fushimi Castle, creepy!

関ヶ原の戦い直前に西軍に落とされた伏見城の床板を供養の為に天井板として使用しているので血天井です。そもそも秀吉の側室であった茶々(淀君)が父、浅井長政の菩提を弔うために建てたお寺です。その後、焼失したのを二代将軍、秀忠の正室、お江の方が再建しています。ちなみに茶々と江は姉妹で、母は信長の妹のお市の方です。小さいお寺ですが当時の政治権力と直結する複雑な人間関係がこの寺には色濃く残っていて興味深いです‼️
It was closed until April 12. The staff were very helpful and I enjoyed the sculpture garden and the ceramic fair featuring some very talented artisans.
Interesting art work. Add this place to your itinerary if you're in the area.

The main building is currently closed due to renovations (until 2019) however my husband and I visited the exhibition currently being held at the annex and were not disappointed. Was a beautiful and very clean space with lovely art pieces and a wonderful exhibit displaying artworks by children in the community. It was very heartwarming to see how Kyoto values creativity and individuality of its young people and was honestly one of the hi-lights of our time in Kyoto.
Dali exhibition! Talk about good timing! 16$ to see everything but the famous works, aka the real bulk of an artists work. Great exhibition.
This is the first museum I visited in Japan. They have always organized the special exhibition event. It's so valuable to spend time there.
It gets VERY packed with local people when the festival is held. Very nice festival with a lot ofgood food.
Visited for the Setsubun event in February. Great experience! Everyone was very open explaing what the whole festival was about. Highly worth visiting!
Interesting shrine, very beautiful.
It is in nature lord krishana/lord Ram they develop themselves in the nature.Prakriti is god.
This image taken on a snowy day.

Nice place, fun walk. Wish I had more time to enjoy it but I opted for the speed tour this time. Give this place a visit if you are in the area! 

It would be a great date site, plenty of places to take pictures.

What a nice place to spend a few hours.  A very interesting place with a very interesting history.  I even got to build my own Zen garden! There are staff throughout the place who can explain the details.

We came to see the robot Buddha... it is quite a novelty to me and quite a Japanese thing to be honest. The robot ‘preaches’ about emptiness in a projection/recording. In terms of robotics, I am sure there are more intelligent presentations but the look of the robot is quite inline with the overall religious concept. 
Young children are not allowed to enter as you need to be quiet and you cannot record or take photo when the robot is in action. 
Temple grounds is beautiful.

Their Japanese zen garden is very beautiful. Inside the temple is very beautiful nature, peaceful, and calm. I would.like to visit here again. There is museam, tea house, and walking street with many shops for souveniers around the temple. They also have good coffee cafe too.

(Visits: ~3) Kyoto is a real mixed bag these days. WAY too many tourists. Its near impossible to enjoy anything. This temple was awesome. A lot to see here and in the area. There were not too many people so we were able to set our own pace and enjoy the time the time. That being said we got there very early, around 9:30 am. By the time we left the area and started to head to Kiyomizudera the tsunami of people was already so great that we just left and went home.

Quite a beautiful temple and garden. However they should do something about the discipline of foreign visitors:

- A man was lying on the side of the pond as if it was a beach (his belly was even showing!)
- A family was walking over the bridge of the pond and inside the restricted garden
- Several people where wearing their shoes on the tatami mats 

It’s not necessary to tolerate this inappropriate behaviour.
Absolutely stunning! Extremely well kept. The gardens in particular are beautiful

A beautiful little temple where you can walk through traditional tatami rooms. There seemed to be a cafe where you could buy drinks and drink them in the rooms, but I wasn't paying much attention. Also, there were very few people, even compared to the surrounding temples (in January).

I visited here on 06 Apr 2019 when cherry blossoms were in full bloom.
From 18:00, they have special night opening and illumination during this Sakura season.
I entered at 18:00, it was still not dark so I could enjoy inside of the temples and garden.
The garden is huge and has variety of spots to see. Sakura trees, pond, carps, teahouse, bamboo forest and a small shrine on the hill.
Walking along, I felt like I was wandering in a different world.
In one hour, it got dark enough to enjoy night illumination.
I was fully satisfied to see this place both under sunlight and in darkness.

Wonderful temple far from the chaotic center of the city. 
Inside the temple there's an "indoor" garden with a small pond full of fishes and most of the rooms can be entered or at least seen from outside.
There's a small watchtower on the hill near the temple that gives an incredible view of the city.
Fewer tourists than the other temples of Kyoto come to this temple and that's really a plus.

Adult entrance fee at ¥300, huge statue of Guan Yin (Goddess of Mercy) to commemorate the fallen soldier during the war, you can also pay your respect to Buddha and Guan Yin here, very calm and serene environment.
Its as good as it gets. there is a 300 yen entrance fee,
Somewhat worth a visit.

A memorial for "fallen patriotic heroic martyrs". Over-zealous gate attendant kept pushing us to light the incense and pay respect to fallen solders. Putting historical differences aside, the experience left a sour taste, which unfortunately blemishes the otherwise beautiful Kyoto experience.
Kannon = Avalokitsvara = Guan Yin = Goddess of Mercy.
Nothing great. Other shrines are better. The robot act was very poor.
A good place to stop and sit.
good!

幕末志士の軌跡を巡る為に立ち寄りました。
日本で一番有名であろう幕末の英雄『坂本龍馬』は同じ土佐出身の『中岡慎太郎』と共に此方に埋葬されておりました。

帰り際に偶然やたら大きい立派な碑があるなぁと思い近づいて見るとビックリ！
第二次大戦後に行われた『東京裁判』にて唯一異を唱えた事でも有名な『パール判事』の碑でした。

今の日本の礎を築いたと言われる高名な方々に想いを馳せて訪れると感慨深い気持ちになります🙏

京都出身者の戦没者を祭る神社です。
全国に有る護国神社の一つで、ここ京都出身者は第二次世界大戦ではビルマ・沖縄と過酷な戦場へ出征されています。
ビルマでは補給を考えない無理な作戦で多くの将兵がマラリアと飢えで無くなられました。
ある師団では、再三の補給要請に応えない上層部に無断で師団を撤退させるという陸軍始まって以来の抗命罪事件が起こり、結局補給の目途が立たずインパール攻略を取りやめ撤退しますが、前述のように飢えとマラリアで次々と倒れ約6万人投入しチンドウィン川を渡河し戻ってこれたのは約2600人で、この内2000人は入院が必要な重症患者であり、その後約400人が死亡しました。
未だビルマ（現ミャンマー）の密林には、御遺骨が野ざらしにされています。

沖縄戦では、大本営が最精鋭師団である第9師団を台湾へ転属させたため、陣地交代が起こり京都出身者で編成された第62師団が米軍上陸地点の北谷町から首里に至る範囲の防衛にあたり、沖縄線前半の主力となりました。
62師団はベテランらしく、彼我兵力差をものともせず、我に数倍する敵を良く食い止め順次戦線を後退させました。
前半の激戦地の一つである嘉数には京都の碑が建立されており、現在もトーチカが残っているなど当時の戦闘の痕跡を見ることが出来ます。

また、坂本龍馬の墓へお参りする人が多いです。併設の資料館は幕末の刀剣類など数多く展示してあり幕末好きにはたまらないでしょう。

京都出身戦没者の御霊の安らかな眠りを祈ります。

Oldest Zen temple in Japan. The raked gardens are a real treat here. Very calm and soothing to the spirit. I would definitely recommend a visit if you are in Kyoto. It's also not too far to walk to the Geisha district from here.
Kindly note that there will be a lot of other visitors to this beautiful place, don't forget to wear socks. Enjoy.

This was a great experience. This temple is over 800 years old! It is so beautiful and full of authentic history.

The twin dragons painting was definitely a sight to see!

Artwork was nice and so were the temple grounds but there really isn't much of too much real significance here but the highly advertised nature of this temple means there is plenty of swag available for purchase.

Nice place to visit though, but definitely for tourists.
Stunningly beautiful Zen Temple complex. Beautiful screens. The birthplace of tea. Fabulous rock garden, and  a temple with dragons on the ceiling.

Gorgeous but ironically overrun by loud tourists posing for photos whole destroying any meditative zen. I imagine in years to come entrance will be regulated, but for now brave yourself, especially on weekends.

An amazing little secret spot in Kyoto. Nobody was there but us, and the place is so beautiful. It’s the perfect place to soak in the atmosphere of tranquility in Kyoto and to experience the beauty of nature in Japan.
Tranquil temple. The garden is superb with nice Japanese bonsai
Loved this park, I was the only person there when I went and it feels somewhah mystical.
When I visited this temple it appeared to be under construction or maintenance so there wasn't anything to see. On the bright side it was very peaceful and no entry fee was required.

Despite Lonely Planet highlighting this place with their star, as a "hidden treasure of Kyoto", I found little to nothing interesting. There's just a very small though lovely garden. The rest is closed to the public. It might prove tricky to find due to the lack of English signs after some point. Unless you have some good-for-nothing spare time, it is not worth a deviation from the Philosopher's Path.
Nice place to visit

京都非公開文化財特別公開で、13年ぶりに公開された東福門院(徳川秀忠の娘、和子)の菩提寺です。
少しわかりづらい所にありますが、永観堂の北側で哲学の道のすぐ西側にあります。
仏殿には釈迦如来像等、とても優しいお顔の仏様を拝見することが出来ます。
琵琶湖疎水より水がひかれている池のある美しい庭があり、ゆっくりとした気持ちにさせてくれます。
ただ、お庭は解放されておらず、廊下も開け放たされていなく、窓越しにお庭の写真を撮る事も許されていなかったのはとても残念でした。

哲学の道からよく見える重層の立派な仏殿が気になっていたので、平成３０年の特別公開に行ってきました。東福門院和子の念持仏の聖観音は気品のあるお顔立ちで、運慶作という言い伝えも信憑性が高いのではないでしょうか。それよりも印象に残ったのは東福門院の遺髪が展示されていたことです。徳川秀忠とお江の娘で後水尾上皇の中宮だった人の黒髪を間近に見て、歴史というものを改めてリアルに感じました。また、東福門院の甥にあたる四代将軍家綱の絵があったのも驚きでした。家綱という人の印象はさっぱり無いのですが、素直で好感の持てる絵でした。

特別公開で東福門院坐像を拝観。
特別な時間が過ごせました。南禅寺の近くにこんなお寺があったとは思いもよりませんでした。
2018年秋の非公開文化財特別公開で拝観しました。東福門院像や聖観音像が公開されました。庭園もきれいでした。

Kyoto, Japan is a city full of historic sites and temples are the major part of it. If you only get a chance to visit one temple, I will recommend you come visit Eikandocho Temple, it has every detail and spirit you can explore. If you have more days to visit Kyoto, you should check all other temples! I am in love with this city and its stories behind. It is a city with an old soul. Hope you enjoy the time like I did.

The red leaf in night is amazing. It’s a must see in Kyoto if you had the chance. I would recommend this over any other night attraction. 

The only problem I have here is it is too crowded. That is the proof of how amazing the view is. Try to be there early as the line get pretty long after 4:30 pm (open at 5:30). Make sure your phone is fully charged as it take very long before you can enter the area.
I want to visit it again in the autumn season. This temple is nicknamed "Eikando of autumnal leaves". Therefore, the beauty of the temple will be in full swing the autumn.
I love this temple although it is not in spring with cherry and not in autumn with foliage. It still has fully charm. Gardens and buildings are very beautiful. Treasures are valuable and rare.
If you visit Kyoto in autumn, this temple is a must see place. You should not miss the light-up here.

If you're looking for a good dessert place to enjoy the green tea flavors of Kyoto, this is the place. The shop has 3 floors. If you want to dine in, you can go to the second or third floor. The prices can be a bit steep, but it's good quality stuff. They have an English menu. Definitely recommend this place.
Away from the hustle of the crowd outside...go up a flight stairs and then wow ! Amazing teas and sundaes....thoroughly recommend this place !

I intend to come here for a Green tea icecream.cone with red bean and dung-ngo,but quite disappointed that they don't offer that at main shop. There are fewer menus here than the Tsujiri shop at Kyoto tower Fl 1. For take away, I recommend the one at Kyoto tower opposite the Kyoto station. However, if you want to eat in there are many many special parfaits menus for you to choose from. I personally think their green tea icecream sweetness is just about right but it a little bit too bitter for me.
Very well presented dessert. Taste not bad too..but it is considered quite pricey.
The complimentary hojicha is so aromatic and good. The dessert with macha icecream is very nice but overall abit pricey

2017年7月10日にお店の名前が「Trattorìa Sorrisso Teru」に変わったそうです
休日ランチ、コースで1,300円いただきました。
セット価格でグラススパークリングなどアルコールも300円で提供されてました
 ちょっとずつ 綺麗に並んだ 前菜盛り合わせ、選べるパスタ、デザート、どれも良かった
冷製スープはビシソワーズ を最初に出されて
このお店は美味しいかも！ってすぐ分かった

路地を入ったところだから、静かで落ち着いてゆっくり楽しめる場所かも

名前と営業時間編集しました(2017.8.13)
インターネットではラクレットが売りのように書かれていますが、店舗に足を運ぶとありませんでした。
雰囲気がいい。飲むだけでも使える。

Beautiful, different to other temples around. It's clearly worth the visit but for sure it will be crowded. Even at 9h15 there were many local and international tourists. It's a quick visit, as you cannot visit the inside of the temple; around 30/45 minutes.

Wow is all I can say about this place.  Nothing will prepare you for the beauty of the temple, overlooking a placid pond with well manicured greenery around it.  It looks like a still painting and beautiful from every angle.  It could get crowded at times with hordes of tourists fighting for the perfect shot but there are certain spots in the park that feels will fill you with zen and calmness.  This place is an absolute visit when in Kyoto.

This is one of the very beautiful Buddhist temple. It's also called golden temple. If you visit Kyoto then you should visit that place. Temple, green trees, pond, walking path all the things in that area made it very special tourist spot in Kyoto. If you want to visit early in the morning then you will be able to avoid the crowd. Otherwise you will have to face the crowd as this is one of the the top attraction point for tourists. But still you will enjoy.

Beautiful golden temple at a fair price. Past the temple are several amazing Zen gardens as well. Like most sights in Kyoto it will be very crowded, but even with the crowds we moved around easily. There are vendors inside selling treats and I recommend trying the ones that look like dumplings made from rice dough as they are very good!

I love this place. It's a nice place to walk around and eat some ice cream. There are a lot of tourists walking around. It can be a little hard to walk around but just walk more inwards to get a better picture. I really recommend visiting.

Tons of things to see and do at this temple. Went during cherry blossom season 2019 and there is a fair amount of construction on many parts but it is still worth it. Just walking around the temple floors and seeing all the rooms the buddhist monks also spent so much time in was inspiring. Why do I not have a open zen like garden space in the middle of my house or in the backyard? I don’t know but now I want to change that. A mental bath. Enjoy.

Thank you for not putting the temple seal behind a ticketed paywall. The temple grounds are expansive and actively used. By chance I was treated to seeing a procession of monks which was an interesting sight. 

The signs explaining terminology were super helpful and made the experience that much more meaningful! Great place!
I think you can skip this one unless you are deeply interested into aspects of its architecture. The gardens are below average and all buildings are closed - besides the ticket office.

Anyone looking for something a little different when visiting Kyoto then I highly recommend a temple stay. Ninna- Ji Temple offer private rooms with shared bathrooms which will allow you to get up at sunrise and pray with the monks. 
The rooms are traditional, along with the breakfast. I used a link which allowed me to book in English and as long as you arrive before 6.30pm then someone who speaks English should be able to check you in. It was such an awesome experience, I highly recommend

This a really cool temple with beautiful gardens that make you feel peaceful. There is set path to walk through. I really liked that some of the rooms had some small furnishings and not just the bare room. There was a room with an informational video so you can see what the grounds look like during other seasons. Reasonable price and totally worth your time to visit.

This shrine has the world's most well loved stone, and is a popular hangout for kids and their mothers. A nice place to pop by or to bring your child. They sell nice charms and have a fairly spacious shrine ground.

Loving this small little temple. Especially the small ones to the side with plants growing on their roofs.
You can find some nice talisman as well. Great souvenirs.
Empty during night and magical, one of the best at night
Aburi-Mochi is famous food of this place.

Sunny morning Imamiya Shrine
Morning to noon around 今宮神社 for desserts, good luck, good health and cleanse off negative energy at the same time.

There are few unique attractions within Imamiya Shrine. Especially, the two old dessert shops Ichiwa and Kazariya. Specialized in roasted rice cakes known as aburi-mochi.

There is also a unique 今宮の奇石 阿呆賢 The Magical Ahokashisan Stone of Imamiya Shrine. Locals visit the stone for its magical elements. When a person touches the stone and then rubs to the injury area, it would assist in faster healing and recovery. The stone has wish granting properties too, by tapping the stone three times, lifts it up and puts it down. Then, strokes the stone again while making a wish, lifts it up and puts it down again.

Lovely area for seeing cherry blossoms. The only issue was that the area was converted into a food / restaurant market and that made it too crowded. There were food stands or dining areas everywhere. The shrine itself is nice.

Chance discovery on the way back from Kikaku-ji. It's a 10 min weekly and is the best place to view cherry blossoms that I've come across in Kyoto. The Cherry garden is full of great trees. Beautiful old shrine too.
Very friendly temple staff. Very english-friendly too! They have a nice Flower Oracle machine in English as well. In the evenings, there are small food shops all over the park.
It was a pretty, but out of cherry blossom season it is pretty dead looking. The is also damage that is still being repaired as of writing.
Wonderful place with cherry blossom

I decided I had some time and took the premium tour. Good thing I did there was an interesting bathhouse and an awesome unryuu (cloud dragon) painting on the ceiling of the temple. Give the head temple a visit if you have time it is certainly worth a trip.

I am a believer of the Aichi Prefecture branch of Myoshin-Temple. So I want to say that Myoshin-Temple is the best temple. The believers in other temples will also say that their temples are the best.
Beautiful and simple. Not busy at all.
Nice temple to see if you are in the area.  I wouldn't make a special trip for it however.
It is quieter than other temples in Kyoto but it is absolutely worth visiting

Beautiful, different to other temples around. It's clearly worth the visit but for sure it will be crowded. Even at 9h15 there were many local and international tourists. It's a quick visit, as you cannot visit the inside of the temple; around 30/45 minutes.

Wow is all I can say about this place.  Nothing will prepare you for the beauty of the temple, overlooking a placid pond with well manicured greenery around it.  It looks like a still painting and beautiful from every angle.  It could get crowded at times with hordes of tourists fighting for the perfect shot but there are certain spots in the park that feels will fill you with zen and calmness.  This place is an absolute visit when in Kyoto.

This is one of the very beautiful Buddhist temple. It's also called golden temple. If you visit Kyoto then you should visit that place. Temple, green trees, pond, walking path all the things in that area made it very special tourist spot in Kyoto. If you want to visit early in the morning then you will be able to avoid the crowd. Otherwise you will have to face the crowd as this is one of the the top attraction point for tourists. But still you will enjoy.

Beautiful golden temple at a fair price. Past the temple are several amazing Zen gardens as well. Like most sights in Kyoto it will be very crowded, but even with the crowds we moved around easily. There are vendors inside selling treats and I recommend trying the ones that look like dumplings made from rice dough as they are very good!

I love this place. It's a nice place to walk around and eat some ice cream. There are a lot of tourists walking around. It can be a little hard to walk around but just walk more inwards to get a better picture. I really recommend visiting.

V recommend to come here as it’s a v nice walk through the whole area. Beautiful place with nice landscape and there is a small water place where one can buy a fortune paper n soak it to read your fortune. There is a temple for beauty where gals will draw pic on the  mirror shaped wood plank and wish for beauty . It’s actually free entry. Plus u can walk to a river where it’s calm n wonderful to just see the ducks n birds enjoying themselves. Walk across the river via the stones. There is a shop that sell a charm with beautiful sound which this is a first time to see.

水くじ was a fun experience, and being able to mostly understand the fortune I got out of it made the experience even better. 

Definitely come with spending money, but there is enough English support to get by. Be sure to check out the shrine to the south for the kagami experience!

We came here by chance by riding bikes from Kyoto Station all the way to here. It was worthwhile and we really enjoyed this place. Full of history and niceties. 

No garbage bins around.

A huge shrine. There are about 10 or so different shrines in this 'Shimogamo' shrine. It doesn't cost anything to look around the shrine and there is a good forest surrounding it called Tadasu no Mori (糺の森) so you could have some fun for a few hours with your family I guess. 
However I do hope you are cultured enough NOT to let your kids into the stream surrounding the shrine like the couple I met when I visited. The shrine is sacred ground for the locals and a tourist attraction, not your babies' backyard. Moreover it kind of stinks to have humans pollute the nature at a tour site. Kids, even more so because they do not know etiquettes yet. I realized that they were taking pictures of their children playing but still, your kids may or may not be adorable to total strangers but let's not make the situation any worse.

At any rate the Shimogamo Shrine is to the northern end of the area. I added all the other shrines to google map though.
Wow. The 2nd best place to be in Kyoto.

This is a very serene place where you can get a glimpse of local people activities. The locals come here to polish their photography skills, doing some paintings, picnic, and strolling. Most of the locals who comes here are senior citizens. The park is very well maintained. Come here, take a stroll and I'm sure you can clear your mind.

Nice scenery. It would be very beautiful in a few days. The conservatory itself is also very nicely arranged. However, as with many other garden, the subjection to blooming time of the different plants can make the visit limited to only areas that has not blossomed.

It’s the most beautiful place that costs only ¥200, and allows for multiple re-entries into the space. Also, an added bonus, is that it’s mostly full with locals and not tourists. It’s a bit farther up north, so it’s not a place that most tourists come and visit. But it’s absolutely stunning at all times throughout the year, as it has quite a large space, and there are so many varieties of flowers that bloom at different times of the year. Also, it’s a very popular place to take wedding photos, CUC many beautiful couples here.

Beautifully maintained botanical garden, with a spectacular conservatory that is well worth the extra 200 yen.

Many majestic trees and flowering plants around the grounds. Some areas are seasonal (for example peonies are not in bloom in April, during cherry blossom season), but the conservatory contains splendid plants year-round and is huge, containing many sections with different climates.

Also on the grounds is a nice playground for kids, with all sorts of climbing opportunities.

Easy to reach by metro; follow the signs for the botanical gardens and you emerge right next to the Kitayama entrance to the garden. Very peaceful place to stroll and enjoy the beauty and diversity of flora!
Great Park where you can enjoy Japanese garden art. Inside there is a restaurant that serves good food and coffee that is not expensive. The conservatorium inside is very worth the additional cost.
I loved to see trees planted in a linear manner. The contrast of trees and Mt. Hiei was so beautiful. Noted on wonder-tips.

Entsuji Temple belongs to Myoshin sect which is a branch of Rinzai sect of Buddhism. It was formerly Hataeda Palace. The temple was built in 1678 by a nun serving a mother of Emperor Gomizuno. When it was built the tenth head of Myoshinji Temple ( in Hanazono ) was appointed to become the first head priest of Entsuji.
The temple holds a wooden block with engraved sutra sent from China and a scrool made by Emperor Reigen as its cultural treasure. The temple is known for the beauty of a Karesansui ( dry stone garden ) with a picturesque borrowed landscape of Mt. Hiei in the backdrop. The view of the Mt. Hiei from here has been designated as a national site of scenic beauty. There are about 40 stones in the garden that are arranged by Emperor Gosuio himself. The main object of worship is Seikannon Statue.

とても静か。鳥の声だけしか聞こえません。心洗われました。
お坊様の説明がテープ？で流れますが、無い方が落ち着いたかな。
お庭以外の写真撮影は不可のようです。日本語でのみ注意喚起されてるので、外国人の方、ご注意下さい。
また季節を変えて訪れたいです。

秋葉の時期がおススメ。
素晴らしい庭です
借景の庭。近年の都市化で苦労しているのがわかりますが、目の前の杉の木を切らないのは慈悲の心からでしょうか。４０年前に買った山渓の写真とかなり違いますが、比叡の姿には感嘆の声を上げました

Such a peaceful place, worth the price of admission any season I'm sure. We stumbled across it on our way to another temple and were so happy to have found it. I only wish they had larger slippers for the garden.
A beautiful, elegant and very peaceful temple.
Beautiful place to sit and be still, enjoyed the peaceful place and took some beautiful pictures.
Love this beautiful place, the view, and the well-maintained garden. It’s my second visit.
Very quiet and cozy little temple in the north east of Kyoto. Highly recommended for those who love the zen feeling in serene atmosphere.

Beautiful temple grounds especially during cherry blossom season. Because it's out of the way in Ohara, also not crowded with tourists. Good restaurants nearby and the walk here from the bus station is gorgeous too, definitely worth the entrance fee and time!
A beautiful place, not too many travellers  but the location is too far. Overall nice to take photo here and totally relax.
Absolutely beautiful. The atmosphere here feels so peaceful. Momiji is gorgeous too. Honestly this place is so much nicer than a lot of crowded places in the city.
Absolutely beautiful, quiet temple, especially in fall—I also went during winter, and it was still beautiful but not quite as stunning.
Amazing garden and temple, especially during sakura
Amidaji

If you miss here during Kyoto trip, you will regret. Hosenin Temple is smaller than Sanjen Temple, however, it is worth a visit to have meditation and refresh. Don’t forget to take free tea and sweet. You should pay it in Other temples.
Beautiful garden with a 700 year old tree. Sipping matcha while taking in the view is a religious experience in itself.
Entrance fee includes a ticket for matcha and sweet tasting. Perfect to have a relaxing time.
great place near Kyoto

Hosenin has a beautiful garden just behind the ticketing counter that most visitors miss out on. The main garden with the 700-year-old tree shaped like Mt Fuji with its blood ceilings from Fushimi Castle are the main attraction, bjt don’t miss out on the other garden either! Entry is expensive at ¥800, but it comes with a bowl of matcha.

Yummy falafel. Several vegan/vegetarian options to choose from. I was pleased with the portion size and price as I expect non-Japanese food to have a bigger price tag. Staff was very kind and helpful. Short walk from the  train station.

Tasty food  good Falafels, veg. and vegan options. Ok for single visitors, comfortable basic feeling and seating. Price a bit high for the portion, but you may be paying for the locally uncommon Israeli food. Norrh of Kyoto, but very close to two connecting train stations.

Delicious, genuine food, a small variety of middle eastern groceries to buy, nice atmosphere and kind staff. You can choose between a lot of main dishes and desserts, both traditional and more mainstream (halva and baklava, but also brownie). Added bonus is vegan and vegetarian options. I personally found the portions fine and felt satisfied, but I can understand that for some people it might be a bit small.
Good quality food. The falafel was good, portions filled me up, and the baklava for dessert was sooo good. I'll be going back again and bringing a bigger appetite.

The Falafel Garden has a gorgeous patio and is a great place to consider if you want something besides Japanese food. It is pretty far off from the town center but you can get there by train quite easily. I found the falafel to be somewhat tasty but the food overall was not one of my favorite eating experiences in Kyoto. The service was also quite slow, not a great place to go to if you are in a rush.

I decided I had some time and took the premium tour. Good thing I did there was an interesting bathhouse and an awesome unryuu (cloud dragon) painting on the ceiling of the temple. Give the head temple a visit if you have time it is certainly worth a trip.

I am a believer of the Aichi Prefecture branch of Myoshin-Temple. So I want to say that Myoshin-Temple is the best temple. The believers in other temples will also say that their temples are the best.
Beautiful and simple. Not busy at all.
Nice temple to see if you are in the area.  I wouldn't make a special trip for it however.
It is quieter than other temples in Kyoto but it is absolutely worth visiting

Loved this place but allow plenty of time to wonder and walk up to the top and back. Lots of street food carts on the way up all full of delicious goodness. Plenty of places to grab a souvenir or two as well. You could easily spend a half day here. Easy to get to by train as well. Recommend travelers spot here for a visit

Ready for a hike? If you want to fully experience this place, plan for most of the day. The shrines and main temple are amazing, as are most. But the inari gates are great to walk through. You can do a short route in 20 minutes, or climb all the way up to Mt. Inari in another 90 minutes (up and back).

The views were great, the place is peaceful and filled with shrines along the way up. It has lights along the path so if you go up late in the day you can still find your way down. There is a scenic view half way up, and the summit is another 45 minutes round trip. The summit has another shrine, no epic view, so most people seemed disappointed they climbed so far for "just another shrine". If you're looking for views, stop half way up. If you just want to see the gates, don't bother doing the hike. 

This was probably the best place to see in Kyoto, and it was free and a good use of time.

one of the best days we had in Japan! Come early and definitely walk the whole path up to the summit and back down to enjoy the whole beauty of the gates, the shrines and the mountain. Most tourists only walk half so  it's pretty quiet the higher you get and also you'll have plenty of great spots for pictures. Also walk through the shrines, cause most tourists stay at the "front"

This is my absolute favourite place to visit in Japan, I've been 3 times now and find something different each trip. The walk up to the top is quite meditative and soothing to the soul. There are little shops to buy drinks, food, offerings and souvenirs. If you take your time it's not a hard trip up. If I were introducing people to Japan and Japanese culture this would be on the top of my list!

Amazing place and walk into nature. The further you go up the less crowds there are. Would suggest planning a few hours here and really taking it all in. Come early or hike further in if you want to take photos without people in them. Really enjoyed my time here!
Nice little traditional inn with historical significance. Very clean.
Too beautiful. It's a amazing place to travel in Japan

Cool little piece of history! This place looks exactly the way it was 200 years ago. 

You can see some of the battle marks through the house. 

Be aware when you come in you must take off your shoes and the place is quite small so be ware bigger people you will have a hard time and will need to bend your head all the time. 

If you are coming with a bicycle there is some space to park it next to the entrance. Usually the guard will help you park your bicycle. 

It is a great historical place. We recommend it strongly!!!
Interesting little place, looking into the history of Japan
As a samurai fan, this is a must go!

Jonangu was the south guardian gate of the ancient capital, Kyoto.
This shrine is believed to have a power to purify bad direction, lead success in construction and transport.
The garden is famous for weeping plum trees.
I visited here on 13th Feb 2019, unfortunately only some of them were in bloom and most of them were still in buds.
But yet they were lovely and worth visiting.
Visited during autumn, vibrant, beautiful very cared for gardens! Only 600 Yen for full access around the shrine. Would definitely visit again in spring.
Mesmerizing Ume Blossoms in March 😍😍😍

A beautiful shrine which is very much less crowded compared to the other attractions. It also offers beautiful views with the plums blossoms and has numerous flowers. You can smell the aroma of the plums when you enter. Do check this place out when you are in Kyoto.
to see plum blossom this is the place must go.

Temple dedicated to Ono no Komachi. We were there during the Hanezu-michi ceremony at the end of March, a show which was well worth the admission. There were blooming plum trees and also a nice walk through the temple itself.
Beautiful garden and temple. The screen painting is exquisite.
I love hanezu-odori.
Quiet and lovely.  Tied to Ono no Komachi.
I love this place！！！！

Amazing and ridiculously photogenic temple during Autumn colors season . All the previous reviews are true and the vistas are well worth the journey, which is fairly straighfoward nowadays with Google maps . Best of all if you come early enough there are few tourists around, almost all of whom are Japanese.. You should plan at least 2 to 3 hours here to allow time to soak in the view. Be warned there is a short but fairly steep walk up to the temple, which should take no more than 10 to 15 minutes.
One of the best temples in Kansai to see Autumn Leaves and Cherry Blossom. Easy to get to and not overcrowded. It's also very cheap and big! Definitely recommend.
You can ride bikes all the way here, tough but fun.

Yoshimine Temple belongs to Tenday sect of Buddhism located in Rakusai district in mountainous region ( Mt. Pon Pon located in the south west of Mt. Oshio ). It was originally established in 1029 by a priest of Enryakuji Temple as his personal retreat. Enryakuji Temple is location up on easter mountain chain of Kyoto, but the temple is a part of Shiga Prefecture. This area was once badly destroyed in the middle of Onin war. Same as its neighboring Konzoji Temple, it was reconstructed by Keishoin so the currect structures are from 17th century. The temple holds some precious assets such as kannon statues curved by priest Gezan presented by Emperor Gosuzaku. Yoshimine Temple is widely known for its impressive size of a pine tree with its branch extends as long as 40 meters although the branch was once more than 50 meters long, but unfortunately the part of the branch was eaten off by insects and it was cut by about 10 meters for its treatment. This 600 year-old pine tree is designated as a natural monument of Japan.   The entire course of making a round of this temple requires quite physical efforts in hiking up the hills up and down since the temple property extensively covers a large mountainous area. there numorous small temple halls and structures connected with long winding poaths along the way. The tour takes about 40 minutes to complete. When you reach up to the top, you can see how the temple commands extensive view toward east. You can see as far in the distance as to see Enryakuji Temple up on Mt. Hiei. 
 To access this location take JR Kyoto Line from Kyoto Station to Mukomachi Station. Another chpoice is to take Hankyu Kyoto Line from central Kyoto to Higashimuko Station. When you arrive at Higashi Muko Station take Hankyu Bus No. 66.

( Trans-word+ : TGM Kyoto Guide )
Valley of cherryblossom.
An amazing Resturant great for meat and chicken, staff are helpful plus they have a English menu. The sake is fanatic too, very authentic and reasonably priced.

We came here as part of a sake tasting your. We were pleasantly that it is a famous free range chicken restaurant! We had the chicken yakitori and chicken donburi. Both were great. The best part was the house brewed cold sake. It was the first but the best sake of our tour!!!
Its so good, delicious japanese style BBQ, but it got have reservation. Its so many customers waiting at the front door.
Great place with fresh sake

Popular yakitori place full of locals.  Make sure to ask for their English menu since they may not offer it even when it's obvious you need one.  Skewers are delicious and have a nice Japanese char aroma.  Make sure to try their other small dishes as well.  There is a button to call a server when you are ready to place your orders.  They have a moderate selection of sakes with a sweetness/dry scale rating.
